statement.tex: \text{What are the maximum and minimum}\\ \text{values of }\\ \quad f(\theta) = \sin^4\theta + \cos^4\theta
\\ \text{Your friend makes the following claim.}\\ \textbf{Is his claim correct?}
\\ \text{Now your friend makes a second claim. }\\ \textbf{Is this claim also correct?}

reason.tex: \begin{align} &y = \sin^4\theta + \cos^4\theta \\ &\implies \dfrac{dy}{d\theta} = \dfrac{d}{d\theta}\sin^4\theta + \dfrac{d}{d\theta}\cos^4\theta \\ &= \underbrace{\left(4\sin^3\theta\cdot\dfrac{d}{d\theta}\sin\theta\right) + \left(4\cos^3\theta\cdot\dfrac{d}{d\theta}\cos\theta\right)}_{\text{Chain Rule}}\\ &= 4\sin^3\theta\cos\theta - 4\cos^3\theta\sin\theta \\ &= 4\sin\theta\cdot\cos\theta\cdot(\sin^2\theta - \cos^2\theta) \end{align} \\ \text{Hence at any extrema point where }\frac{dy}{d\theta} = 0, \\ \quad 4\sin\theta\cdot\cos\theta\cdot(\sin^2\theta - \cos^2\theta) = 0.

options.tex: \text{There are }\textbf{infinite values }\text{ of }\theta\text{ at which}\\ \text{a maxima or a minima could occur.}

reason.tex: \text{An extrema would occur when }\dfrac{dy}{d\theta} = 0.\\ \text{And that can happen }\textbf{if, }\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Condition} & \theta & \text{Example} \\ \hline \sin\theta = 0 & \theta = n\pi & \theta = 0,\pi \\ \hline \cos\theta = 0 & \theta = (2n+1)\frac{\pi}{2} & \theta=\frac\pi{2} \\ \hline \sin^2\theta = \cos^2\theta &\theta = (2n+1)\frac\pi{4} & \theta = -\frac\pi{4},\frac\pi{4}\\ \hline \end{tabular}

options.tex: \text{As there are infinite extrema points, there}\\ \text{would be infinite different extrema values.}

reason.tex: \sin^4\theta = (\sin^2\theta)^2\text{ and }\cos^4\theta = (\cos^2\theta)^2.\\ \text{But notice also that }\\ \begin{align} \sin^4\theta &= \sin^4 (n\pi-\theta) = \sin^4(n\pi + \theta)\in [0,1] \\ \cos^4\theta &= \cos^4 (n\pi-\theta) = \cos^4(n\pi + \theta)\in [0,1] \end{align} \\ \text{What the above means is that if you find }\\ f(\theta)\text{ at some }\theta,\text{ then you will get the same }f(\theta)\\ \text{if you went }n\pi\text{ radians ahead or behind.} \\ \text{Hence, if we find a maximum or a minimum}\\ \text{value at some }\theta,\text{ then that is the only}\\ \text{maximum or minimum value there can be} \\ \text{(as it will only repeat after } \pi\text{ radians).}

\text{At an extrema, }\dfrac{dy}{d\theta} = 0.\text{ Therefore, }\\ \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Extrema when} & \text{Example} & \text{Value} \\ \hline \sin\theta = 0 & \theta = 0 & 1 \\ \hline \cos\theta = 0 & \theta=\frac\pi{2} & 1 \\ \hline \sin^2\theta = \cos^2\theta &\theta = \frac\pi{4} & \dfrac{1}{2}\\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ \text{And as we showed in Step 3, if it is an extrema}\\ \text{at }\theta_1\text{, then it is an extrema for all }\theta.\\ \text{Hence, the maximum and minimum values of }\\ f(\theta)\text{ are }\underline{1\text{ and }\dfrac{1}{2}}\text{ respectively.}
